news.title: Word of the day
news.description:
Public Sector Enterprises
Public Sector Enterprises are companies that are owned by the government.
They are established with the goal of producing goods and services at affordable prices and also to deal with scarcity of any particular good.
Central Public Sector Undertakings are owned by the central govt. State Public Sector Undertakings are owned by state governments.

news.title: 6-day course
news.description:
Theme: tax-saver mutual funds
Day 3: Wednesday
Another crucial fact to realise is that with ELSS, you can only get a tax benefit under section 80C.
Section 80C allows a total tax benefit of up to Rs 1.5 lakh.
Which means, while calculating tax, you can reduce your income by up to Rs 1.5 lakh before calculating tax.
Section 80C is made up of many other components also. You can use insurance, FD investment, etc in section 80C also.
So plan accordingly. You might not need to invest Rs 1.5 lakh in ELSS — you might be able to invest less also.
Any extra amount invested in an ELSS fund will not give you tax benefits. But the extra amount will remain locked-in for 3 years — that is the rule.
So plan your investments and tax carefully.

news.title: Featured question
news.description:
"How the compounding works in mutual fund? Like the gain/loss keeps fluctuating thorugh out the year and beyond so when does the amc actually takes the gain of the fund to give us the compounding return. CAGR is understandable but how it actually works if i have to compare it with bank fd ."
 
The best way to think about mutual fund investment is to think in terms of a real estate investment (and not FD).
When you buy a house, do you get annual returns? Is there a ‘principal’ or ‘interest’?
No.
The price of the house itself goes up.
When you sell the house, you can use the final price of the house, and compare it with the price you bought it at.
Using that, you can find the effective per annum returns of that investment.
It works similarly with mutual funds also.
